results.title: ‘Lightyear’ Opens at No. 2, as ‘Jurassic World’ Holds Strong
results.abstract: The Pixar movie’s estimated $51 million in North American sales fell short of expectations.

multimedia.caption: A young Buzz Lightyear with Sox, his emotional support cat.
A young Buzz Lightyear with Sox, his emotional support cat.

results.title: How Real-Life and Fictional Horror Seeped Into ‘The Black Phone’
results.abstract: Influenced by “Rosemary’s Baby” and “The Devil’s Backbone,” the filmmaker wove details from his childhood into this supernatural movie starring Ethan Hawke.

multimedia.caption: Mason Thames is one of the targets of a murderous Ethan Hawke in “The Black Phone.”
Mason Thames is one of the targets of a murderous Ethan Hawke in “The Black Phone.”
Mason Thames is one of the targets of a murderous Ethan Hawke in “The Black Phone.”

results.title: Cooper Raiff, Arriving Early to the Party
results.abstract: At 25, the indie writer, director and actor is making waves in Hollywood. His second feature, “Cha Cha Real Smooth,” could start a new career chapter.

results.title: Paul Haggis Arrested on Sexual Assault Charges in Italy
results.abstract: Haggis, who wrote and directed the Oscar-winning crime drama “Crash,” was accused of assaulting a woman in Ostuni over the course of two days.
results.byline: By Emma Bubola and Sarah Bahr

multimedia.caption: Paul Haggis, who was arrested on charges of aggravated sexual violence and aggravated personal injuries in Southern Italy. “He is totally innocent,” his lawyer Priya Chaudhry said.
Paul Haggis, who was arrested on charges of aggravated sexual violence and aggravated personal injuries in Southern Italy. “He is totally innocent,” his lawyer Priya Chaudhry said.
Paul Haggis, who was arrested on charges of aggravated sexual violence and aggravated personal injuries in Southern Italy. “He is totally innocent,” his lawyer Priya Chaudhry said.

results.title: Phil Tippett’s World in (Stop) Motion
results.abstract: The animator and visual effects artist, whose credits include “Jurassic Park” and “The Empire Strikes Back,” has directed his passion project, “Mad God.”

results.title: Andy Garcia Is the Father of the Bride in More Ways Than One
results.abstract: The actor, who’s playing the role onscreen and in reality, understands his rigid character: “He’s an amalgamation of everybody I’ve ever known, including myself.”

multimedia.caption: Garcia said his decision to act was concerning to his father, whose conception of actors ran to stars like Humphrey Bogart: “I’m sure in the back of his mind he said, ‘I love my son, but he’s no Humphrey Bogart.’”
multimedia.copyright: Daniel Dorsa for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: Garcia said his decision to act was concerning to his father, whose conception of actors ran to stars like Humphrey Bogart: “I’m sure in the back of his mind he said, ‘I love my son, but he’s no Humphrey Bogart.’”

results.title: Emma Thompson and the Challenge of Baring All Onscreen at 63
results.abstract: The actress made the choice to disrobe. Still, she says, it was the most difficult thing she’s ever done in her four-decade career.
des_facet: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande (Movie)

multimedia.caption: If “you want the iconography of the female body to change,” Emma Thompson said, “then you better be part of the change.”
multimedia.copyright: Charlotte Hadden for The New York Times

results.title: Watch Bryce Dallas Howard’s Slow Escape in ‘Jurassic World Dominion’
results.abstract: The director Colin Trevorrow narrates a sequence featuring the actor, a testy Therizinosaurus and a murky pond.

results.title: George Michael Preferred Music to Fame. The Doc He Made Does, Too.
results.abstract: “George Michael: Freedom Uncut,” a film the musician worked on with his longtime collaborator David Austin, tells the story of his professional life via interviews and previously unseen footage.

multimedia.caption: George Michael onstage during his Faith World Tour in 1988. The pop star was at work on a documentary about his career at the time of his death in 2016.
George Michael onstage during his Faith World Tour in 1988. The pop star was at work on a documentary about his career at the time of his death in 2016.

results.title: ‘Civil: Ben Crump’ Review: What Becomes of a Missed Opportunity?
results.abstract: The documentary “Civil” follows Ben Crump, the prominent attorney who has represented families affected by police violence, for one turbulent year.

results.title: Jean-Louis Trintignant, Star of Celebrated European Films, Dies at 91
results.abstract: For 50 years, in movies like “A Man and a Woman” and “My Night at Maud’s,” his specialty was playing the flawed Everyman.

multimedia.caption: Jean-Louis Trintignant in the 1960s. In contrast to French film stars like the wisecracking Jean-Paul Belmondo, the working-class hero Jean Gabin and the suave sophisticate Maurice Chevalier, Mr. Trintignant was known for performances that were understated.

Jean-Louis Trintignant in the 1960s. In contrast to French film stars like the wisecracking Jean-Paul Belmondo, the working-class hero Jean Gabin and the suave sophisticate Maurice Chevalier, Mr. Trintignant was known for performances that were understated.

Jean-Louis Trintignant in the 1960s. In contrast to French film stars like the wisecracking Jean-Paul Belmondo, the working-class hero Jean Gabin and the suave sophisticate Maurice Chevalier, Mr. Trintignant was known for performances that were understated.

results.title: A Filmmaker Imagines a Japan Where the Elderly Volunteer to Die
results.abstract: The premise for Chie Hayakawa’s film, “Plan 75,” is shocking: a government push to euthanize the elderly. In a rapidly aging society, some also wonder: Is the movie prescient?

multimedia.caption: Chie Hayakawa in Tokyo. Her new film “Plan 75” takes on one of the biggest elephants in the room in Japan: the challenges of dealing with the world’s oldest society.
multimedia.copyright: Noriko Hayashi for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: Chie Hayakawa in Tokyo. Her new film “Plan 75” takes on one of the biggest elephants in the room in Japan: the challenges of dealing with the world’s oldest society.

results.title: ‘Cha Cha Real Smooth’ Review: The Boy in the Bubble
results.abstract: A recent college graduate moves back home, drifts along and strikes up an unlikely friendship with a single mother in this Sundance indie.

multimedia.caption: Cooper Raiff, left, with Evan Assante in “Cha Cha Real Smooth.” In the film, which he also directed and wrote, he plays a recent college grad who works at a fast-food joint.

results.title: In the Documentaries of the Blackwood Brothers, Great Artists Are Explored
results.abstract: Several films from Michael and Christian Blackwood, grounded in the nitty-gritty of art-making, are available to watch through June 28.

results.title: ‘My Fake Boyfriend’ Review: Deepfake Dating
results.abstract: A gay man gets trapped in a web of lies after his overeager best friend concocts an artificial relationship for him on social media.

results.title: ‘Stay Prayed Up’ Review: Spreading the Gospel of Love
results.abstract: A new documentary about the gospel ensemble the Branchettes and its guiding light, Lena Mae Perry, is a plain-spoken tribute.

results.title: ‘Bitterbrush’ Review: Alone on the Range
results.abstract: Though this quiet documentary about two young range riders recalls a western or two, it presents a modern-day portrait of hard work and friendship.

results.abstract: This latest Joseph Kosinski film — set in a penitentiary that dispenses aphrodisiacs and fear-inducers — couldn’t be more unlike his “Top Gun: Maverick.”

results.title: ‘A Man of Integrity’ Review: Fighting Dirty
results.abstract: Mohammad Rasoulof’s scathing drama about corruption in Iran is striking in its blunt rage, if somewhat exasperating in its monotony.

results.title: Kevin Spacey, Accused of Sexual Assault, Appears in British Court
results.abstract: The proceedings are a rare example of a celebrity #MeToo case leading to criminal charges.

results.title: Disney’s ‘Lightyear,’ With a Same-Sex Kiss, Faces a Backlash in Some Muslim Countries
results.abstract: The United Arab Emirates banned the animated film, an offshoot of the “Toy Story” movies, from its cinemas. Censors in Indonesia and Malaysia are also considering restrictions.

multimedia.caption: Alisha Hawthorne, voiced by Uzo Aduba, in a scene from “Lightyear.” The character kisses her wife in one scene, which has prompted restrictions on the film in some countries.
Alisha Hawthorne, voiced by Uzo Aduba, in a scene from “Lightyear.” The character kisses her wife in one scene, which has prompted restrictions on the film in some countries.
